turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Fibromyalgia.
turn.1: What is the evidence for Fibromyalgia?
turn.2: CBT and related psychological and behavioural therapies have a small to moderate effect in reducing symptoms of fibromyalgia.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: Effect sizes tend to be small when CBT is used as a stand-alone treatment for FM patients, but these improve significantly when CBT is part of a wider multidisciplinary treatment program.
turn.5: Is there anything else noteable about the evidence?
turn.6: The greatest benefit occurs when CBT is used along with exercise.
turn.7: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.8: A 2010 systematic review of 14 studies reported that CBT improves self-efficacy or coping with pain and reduces the number of physician visits at post-treatment, but has no significant effect on pain, fatigue, sleep or health-related quality of life at post-treatment or follow-up.
turn.9: Is there anything else noteable about the article?
turn.10: Depressed mood was also improved but this could not be distinguished from some risks of bias.
turn.11: What are some other interesting aspects?
turn.12: Mind-body therapies focus on interactions among the brain, mind, body and behaviour.
